column1: #Text=If you 're visiting the Achterhoek and would like to take in the stunning landscapes it has to offer , try exploring the region by bike .
#Text=The Netherlands has a high number of bikes per citizen and the Achterhoek is no exception to that .
#Text=The seventeen million citizens of the Netherlands own a grand total of 19 million bikes in total , which makes it the country with the highest bike density .
#Text=Find the closest location that may lend you bikes .

#Text=The local Tourist Office ( VVV ) will most likely be able to give you an address where you can rent bikes , and if not , some bikeshops ( fietsenwinkel ) will be willing to lend you a bike , while outdoor companies can lend you ( mountain)bikes .
#Text=If travelling from a train station to another train station , an OV-fiets may be something you 'd like to consider .
#Text=The Achterhoek has no different etiquette for cyclists than the rest of the Netherlands .
#Text=Always stay on the right side of the road
#Text=If a designated bike lane ( see image ) is available , use that lane .
#Text=When turning a corner , use your hand to indicate where you are planning to go .
#Text=If the road consists of multiple turning lanes , move into the lane that corresponds to the way you are going .
#Text=to other road users coming from your right or on a priority road .
#Text=Always keep your eyes on the road
#Text=The scenery may be beautiful , but safety is still the number one priority .
#Text=Always obey road signs and other directions given
#Text=If something has happened to disrupt the regular flow of traffic , signs or people will be there to regulate traffic .
#Text=Below are multiple cycling routes in the Achterhoek listed on the website of the Foundation National Cycling Platform ( Stichting Landelijk Fietsplatform ) .
#Text=The websites link to PDF files available on their website , ready to be printed .
#Text=They are in Dutch , but visually show the cycling notes and the distance between them , alongside a map of the region with the route on it .

#Text=If you would like to get to your next destination or just spend more than a day cycling through the region , then LF-routes , or Longer Distance routes , may be something you would be interested in .
#Text=The following LF-routes go through the Achterhoek :
#Text=( 135 kilometers ) ( Millingen a/d Rijn - Westervoort - Doesburg - Zutphen - Deventer
#Text=A route passing by most of the Hanze-cities , amongst which is Zutphen .
#Text=Most of the route follows the river IJssel .
#Text=( 300 kilometers ) ( The Hague - Zoetermeer - Utrecht - Arnhem - Vorden - Enschede
#Text=A route cutting straight through the middle of the Netherlands , giving you an impression of all that it has to offer .
#Text=( 260 kilometers ) ( Alkmaar - Hoorn - Enkhuizen - Lelystad - Kampen - Zwolle - Hengelo - Enschede
#Text=A route showing you all the countrysides that the Netherlands has to offer including the tulip industry in North Holland and farming in newly gained land , Flevoland .
#Text=( 270 kilometers ) ( Millingen a/d Rijn - Arnhem - Rhenen - Wijk bij Duurstede - Dordrecht - Hook of Holland
#Text=A route following the entirety of the river Rhine throughout the Netherlands .

#Text=( 1300 kilometers ) ( Arnhem - Vorden - Enschede - Hardenberg - Emmen - Groningen - Den Oever - Beverwijk - Haarlem - The Hague - Bergen op Zoom - Breda - Eindhoven - Roermond - Venlo - Nijmegen - Arnhem
#Text=The ultimate route for a vacation by bike .
#Text=You will get to see nearly all that the Netherlands has to offer , while staying as close to the borders as possible .
#Text=( 180 kilometers ) ( Enschede - Hengelo - Rijssen - Ommen - Oldenzaal - Enschede
#Text=A route that shows you all of Twente , located directly north of the Achterhoek .
